Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on cyber-physical systems applications to power grid, Boston, MA, July 16-17, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The electricity grid of the 21st century is transforming into a complex cyber-physical system (CPS) with unprecedented innovations in architectures, technologies, participants and assets, controls, communications, and market mechanisms. While the benefits of the application of CPS technologies and philosophy to the emerging Smart Grid are self-evident, there are rising concerns of: a) associated cybersecurity; b) integration of renewable energy sources; c) the validation and verification of results from research before incorporating them in a critical infrastructure domain such as the electricity grid; and, d) the preparation and education of the next generation workforce in the power and energy area. These are new topics of research interest in the area of electric power systems engineering and elicits attention from academia, government, and industry alike. The participants will include experts in the power and energy area from the industry, government, and academia that are attending the IEEE PES conference as well as some selected experts general areas of CPS. This workshop is expected to generate synergistic research interests among researchers, while helping identify newer themes for future research funding this area. The workshop will also explicitly address the integration of current and best practices in the area into the education of the future workforce. The benefits of this workshop are germane to the strengthening of a critical infrastructure, i.e., the grid, and the preparation of an educated workforce.

The goal and scope of this workshop includes the exchange of information on best practices, current trends, and topics for future research and education in the application of CPS technologies to power and energy systems. The physical and cyber security of the future electricity grid of the future is paramount. The future grid is also expected to be powered by cleaner sources of generation than in the past, such as renewable energy source that may exhibit inherent stochasticity. It is imperative to develop tools and techniques for assessing the impact of these new technologies on the power grid. The wide acceptance of academic research in these areas is dependent on the validation of the results using realistic environments. One of the enablers for conducting such validation studies and presenting highly reliable results to the industry is the use of testbeds. Lastly, all of the above themes relate to the preparation of a highly-trained workforce that will face the challenges of operating and managing the complex grid of the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary

The electricity grid of the 21st century is transforming into a complex cyber-physical system (CPS) with unprecedented innovations in architectures, technologies, participants and assets, controls, communications, and market mechanism. While the benefits of the application of CPS technologies and philosophy to the emerging Smart Grid are self-evident, there are rising concerns of associated cybersecurity. This is a new topic of research interest in electric power systems engineering and elicits attention from academia and industry alike. The grid of the future is also expected to be powered by cleaner sources of generation than in the past, such as renewable energy source that may exhibit inherent stochasticity. It is imperative to develop tools and techniques for assessing the impact of these new technologies on the power grid. The wide acceptance of academic research in these areas is dependent on the validation of the results using realistic environments. One of the enablers for conducting such validation studies and presenting highly reliable results to the industry is the use of testbeds. Lastly, all the above themes relate to the preparation of a highly-trained workforce that will face the challenges of operating and managing the complex grid of the future.

Thus, the themes of the proposed workshop included: cybersecurity; integration of renewable energy sources; testbeds for validation; and, education germane to CPS topics in power systems engineering. 46 participants from academia, industry, government, and national labs were selected from the power and energy area, controls area, and CPS engineering to participate in the workshop. This enabled the participants to learn about best practices in these areas and seek collaboration. The two-day workshop was held on July 16 and 17, 2016 at the Westin Copley Place Hotel in Boston, MA.

Outcomes

The workshop served as a forum for exchanging important new results from research and education practices on CPS for power engineering. Further, the following key points were identified as the status quo in this field:

  • CPS is identified as an emerging area of utmost importance to electric power systems engineering with potential impacts on security, operation, big data, protection, and resource allocation
  • Researchers focused on electric power systems engineering from large multi-institutional centers and individual institutions alike in the US are conducting research and education activities in this area
  • NSF and other federal agencies are actively supporting research and education in this area
  • The electric power industry is focused on the resilience of the grid as a function of CPS
  • Distributed control, transactive energy, and agent-based operation are garnering interest in the research on CPS for power engineering
  • Testbeds and other educational resources are being developed and deployed in various universities in the US for research, education, and training on CPS topics
  • Several national labs are engaged in cutting-edge research and demonstration in the areas of CPS including testbed development, integration of renewables, and multi-lab resource coordination efforts.

 Intellectual merit

The workshop addressed topics of interest in CPS for electric power and energy systems that will extend the state-of-the-art, with the intent to generate synergistic research interests among researchers, while helping identify newer themes for future research funding this area. The workshop also explicitly addressed the integration of current and best practices in the research areas into the education of the future workforce.

Broader impact

The workshop was conducted over a two-day period (July 16 and 17, 2016) in Boston, MA prior to the IEEE Power and Energy Society General Meeting (GM 2016). The outcomes of this workshop have the potential to inform and impact the research and educational needs of the future in the power and energy area with integration of CPS concepts. All presentations from the workshop are hosted in the public domain at https://goo.gl/vguv5m for wider distribution.
